verses.text: Let a man regard us in this way: as servants of Christ and stewards of the mysteries of God.
verses.comment: Paul emphasizes his role as a servant (literally, an under-rower) and steward, entrusted with divine mysteries. This language suggests the importance and responsibility given to leaders in the apostolic tradition, hinting at a sense of sacred stewardship of teaching and the sacraments, which continue to be handed down.

verses.text: Now, moreover, it is required of stewards that they be found faithful.
verses.comment: Faithfulness in stewardship reflects the necessity for leaders to preserve and rightly handle what they have received. This sets up the idea of a continuous and faithful transmission of truth.

verses.text: But to me it is a very small thing that I should be judged by you or by a human court; indeed, I do not even judge myself.
verses.comment: Paul asserts that human judgment is secondary compared to God's judgment. He shows humility, recognizing he cannot be his own judge, highlighting the need for a divine standard.

verses.text: For I am not aware of anything against myself, yet I am not justified by this. It is the Lord who judges me.
verses.comment: Paul underscores that only Christ's judgment matters. Even with a clear conscience, ultimate justification comes from the Lord's assessment, not our own.

verses.text: Therefore do not pronounce judgment before the time, before the Lord comes, who will both bring to light the hidden things of darkness and will disclose the purposes of the hearts. Then each will receive praise from God.
verses.comment: Paul points to the final judgment, when Christ returns and reveals hidden motives. This serves as a call to patience and humility regarding the spiritual state of others—an argument for unity and trust in God's providence.

verses.text: Now these things, brothers, I have applied to myself and Apollos for your benefit, so that you may learn not to go beyond what is written, so that none of you may be puffed up in favor of one against another.
verses.comment: Paul’s insistence on not going 'beyond what is written' points to the central role of the written Word, but also assumes a faithful interpretation alongside apostolic authority. The focus is on humility and unity.

verses.text: For who makes you differ from another? And what do you have that you did not receive? But if you did receive it, why do you boast as if you had not received it?
verses.comment: Every good thing is received as a gift from God, not earned. This corrects spiritual pride and points to a deep dependency on God’s grace—a core of apostolic teaching.

verses.text: Already you have all you want! Already you have become rich! Without us you have become kings! And would that you did reign, so that we might reign with you.
verses.comment: Paul’s sarcasm rebukes premature self-exaltation and presumption, reminding believers that the fullness of the kingdom is not yet fully realized.

verses.text: For I think that God has exhibited us apostles last of all, as men sentenced to death, because we have become a spectacle to the world, to angels, and to men.
verses.comment: Apostolic suffering is seen as witnessing both to creation and to the heavenly realms, underlining the cost of true apostolic ministry.

verses.text: We are fools for Christ’s sake, but you are wise in Christ; we are weak, but you are strong; you are honored, but we are despised.
verses.comment: Paul draws a contrast to highlight the humility and seeming foolishness of those who follow Christ wholeheartedly, subverting worldly values.

verses.text: To this very hour we hunger and thirst, we are poorly clothed, roughly treated, and are homeless,
verses.comment: The hardships endured by the apostles are an ongoing proof of their dedication and conformity to Christ, who suffered for the sake of the Church.

verses.text: and we labor, working with our own hands. When reviled, we bless; when persecuted, we endure;
verses.comment: Living out Christ’s command to bless those who curse you shows the apostles imitating Christ as the model for all believers.

verses.text: when slandered, we entreat. We have become like the scum of the world and the refuse of all things, even now.
verses.comment: Paul’s description reflects the world’s rejection of Christ’s chosen. The humbling identification with Christ’s suffering is stressed here.

verses.text: I do not write these things to shame you, but to admonish you as my beloved children.
verses.comment: Paul speaks with fatherly love. His corrective discipline is meant to build up, not tear down—revealing the pastoral heart of a true spiritual father.

verses.text: For though you have countless guides in Christ, you do not have many fathers. For in Christ Jesus I became your father through the gospel.
verses.comment: Paul describes his spiritual paternity, laying out the foundational principle of spiritual fatherhood. This spiritual leadership is rooted in apostolic succession, which ensures continuity and unity within the community of believers.

verses.text: Therefore I urge you, be imitators of me.
verses.comment: Paul’s invitation to imitation echoes Christ’s call to discipleship—a model of apostolic authority handed on for the sake of the faithful.

verses.text: That is why I sent you Timothy, my beloved and faithful child in the Lord, to remind you of my ways in Christ, as I teach everywhere in every church.
verses.comment: Apostolic teaching is consistently passed down through entrusted persons like Timothy—showing a unified tradition and structure for Christian life across all communities.

verses.text: Now some are arrogant, as though I were not coming to you.
verses.comment: Some believers in Corinth questioned Paul’s authority, thinking distance weakened his oversight. Paul will soon address the necessity for proper respect for his office.

verses.text: But I will come to you soon, if the Lord wills, and I will find out not the talk of these arrogant ones but their power.
verses.comment: Paul shows pastoral concern and the reality of apostolic authority that is evident not merely in words, but in the transforming power of the Spirit.

verses.text: For the kingdom of God is not a matter of talk but of power.
verses.comment: The true church is known not by eloquence alone, but by the real presence and power of God at work in her midst—a sign of divine authority and the Spirit’s presence.

verses.text: What do you wish? Shall I come to you with a rod, or with love and a spirit of gentleness?
verses.comment: Paul offers the Corinthians a choice: repentance and humility will bring gentle correction, while stubbornness brings stronger discipline. It reflects a pastoral concern for the spiritual health of the community under his apostolic care.
